conbody.p:
categorizes content into five information types:
Tasks Provide procedural information, typically providing step-by-step instructions for accomplishing a goal. A task typically answers a "How Do I..." question.
Troubleshooting Topics Provide strategies for isolating and solving potential problems end users might encounter using products. A troubleshooting topic typically answers a "How Do I Identify and Resolve..." question.
Concepts Provide overview and background information that helps end users understand essential information about a product, interface, or task. A concept topic typically answers a "What is..." question. Conceptual information is read once or twice to provide the necessary background information required to complete a task.
References Provide "look-up" information that end users might need to refer to when completing a task. A reference topic may answer questions like "How Much...", "How Many...", or "What Form..." It is intended to be referred to frequently, as-needed, perhaps while an end user is completing a task.
Glossary Terms Provide definitions of terms and acronyms used within the documentation.
All content must be placed into topics that are based on one of these basic information types. As you work, take care not to mix information types within a single topic file. You can always combine topics by placing them in relation to each other in a DITA map.
